course_title: Law of Contract I: Principles of Contractual Agreement

learning_outcomes.description: Identify the key contractual (and relevant non-contractual) issues in factual scenarios.
Demonstrate a sound knowledge and conceptual understanding of the rules, principles and authorities relating to the formation and content of contractual agreements.

Apply the relevant legal rules, principles and authorities to factual scenarios to present legally defensible arguments and conclusions as to the rights and obligations of parties to contractual agreements.
Respond to legal questions in a structured and logical fashion, communicating answers clearly and coherently.

assessments.due_date:
Peer-Marking task takes place during your tutorial in Week 4 16/03/2026 - 20/03/2026

Self-Reflection and Revision task due 2pm Friday 27 March 27/03/2026 - 27/03/2026
assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Participation/ Student contribution, Reflection, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
This is a two-part task. Each Part will contribute 10% to your overall course grade.

Part A: IN-CLASS PEER-MARKING TASK (10%)

Part A will take place during Week 4 tutorials. Students are required to bring a hard copy of their pre-prepared response to the tutorial question. During the tutorial, responses will be distributed among students. Each student will anonymously assess another student's response against the course criteria. At the end of the tutorial, the marked responses will be returned to their original authors.

Purposes of Part A

This exercise is designed to:

  • develop students' legal writing skills;
  • enhance understanding and application of the assessment criteria; and
  • promote active participation in tutorials.

Requirements

  • Students must attend the tutorial for which they are enrolled. Students will be marked off the roll for that tutorial.
  • Students must bring valid personal identification, including evidence of their UQ student number.

Students who attend and actively participate in the marking and feedback exercise will receive the full 10% allocated for Part A.

Active participation requires bringing a hard copy of your own response and completing the marking and feedback process during your tutorial.

Failure to attend, failure to bring your own response, or failure to participate will result in zero marks for Part A.

PART B: SELF-REFLECTION AND REVISION TASK (10%)

Reflecting on what you learned in the Week 4 tutorial and the feedback you received, you are required to revise your answer to the tutorial question. Your revised work should show that you have engaged with the tutorial discussion and feedback, and have critically reflected on the content of your original response. You should aim for your revised response to be a clear and relevant improvement from your original response. Specifically, you should reflect on and make improvements to the following:

·        identification of the relevant issues;

·        articulation of the relevant law;

·        application and analysis;

·        strength of your conclusion;

·        communication, including clarity of expression and structure.

You must then submit both your original response and your revised response on Blackboard. Your revised response must be in mark-up (‘track changes’) so that we can see the changes you have made.

You must include a completed AI Assignment Coversheet with your submission. Failure to do so may constitute academic misconduct.

Due date for Part B: 2pm Friday 27 March.

If your revised response shows that you have engaged critically with the tutorial content and made clear and relevant improvements to your original response, you will receive the full 10% for Part B.

If your revised response shows that you have engaged with the tutorial content and made clear improvements to your original response, you will receive 5% for Part B.

If your revised response shows that you have not engaged with the tutorial content or have made little or no changes to your original response, you will receive 0% for Part B.

Word count

There is no word limit for this task. Your focus should be on the quality of your legal analysis (not on the word count). As a rough guide, your response should be at least 500 words but no more than 1,000 words.

Feedback

You will not receive individual feedback on this task. However, the Course Coordinator will read your revised responses and will release whole-of-cohort feedback, to assist you with subsequent assessment tasks.

Use of AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Although students are not forbidden to use Artificial Intelligence and/or Machine Translation technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Academic misconduct may become part of a report that UQ must provide to the Legal Practitioners Admissions Board, and this may impact whether you can be admitted to legal practice.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
You will be presented with a question in the form of a hypothetical fact scenario. This task requires you to solve the legal problem(s) presented in the question in the form of a written legal advice.

The question will be released on the Learn.UQ (Blackboard) site for the course on Thursday 9 April at 2pm.

Your Legal Advice is due by 2pm Thursday 16 April.

This Legal Advice should be no more than 1,100 words. You must state the word count on the first page of your response. Any student found to have provided a false word count will be referred to the Academic Integrity Officer. All references (see below) count towards the word limit. If your answer is longer than 1,100 words, you will be marked down in the ‘Communication’ criterion.

You must not discuss the question with anyone else during the duration of the assessment task. Any student found to have done so will be referred to the Academic Integrity Officer.

You must include a completed AI Assignment Coversheet with your submission. Failure to do so may constitute academic misconduct.

Referencing

You should refer to cases and legislation in the main body text. This will also be the referencing style that you will use in the End-of-semester Exam.

All references to cases or legislation should be italicised.

You may refer to cases and legislation using short-hand names (eg 'Carlill').

Do NOT use footnotes.

Do NOT include case citations (eg do not write 'Carlill [1893] 1 QB 256 (CA)').

You should only refer to cases and legislation that are listed in the Learning Guide, contained in the Course Materials volume, or have been discussed in class.

UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES SHOULD YOU REFERENCE AN OUTPUT GENERATED BY AN AI OR MACHINE TRANSLATION TOOL AS AUTHORITY FOR A LEGAL PROPOSITION.

Procedural matters

Please use an appropriate font style and size (eg 12-point Times New Roman or 11-point Arial).

Please proof-read your submission. If your answer contains spelling or grammatical errors, you will be marked down in the 'Communication' criterion.

Grading criteria and feedback

Your Legal Advice will be marked according to criteria and standards which are made available to you via a criteria sheet on Blackboard. Feedback will be provided to the cohort as a whole. You will also receive some individual feedback.

IT Issues

It is your responsibility to ensure that your assignment has been properly submitted. Computer and internet-related issues are not grounds for an extension.

Use of AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Although students are not forbidden to use Artificial Intelligence and/or Machine Translation technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Academic misconduct may become part of a report that UQ must provide to the Legal Practitioners Admissions Board, and this may impact whether you can be admitted to legal practice.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Your Legal Advice must be submitted electronically via Turnitin. A submission link will be provided.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
You will be required to respond to multiple problem-style questions. The exam paper will indicate the proportion of marks assigned to each question. Any of the questions may mix material from different aspects of the examinable topics. 

Examinable material

The End-of-semester Exam may examine material covered throughout the course, from the first week to the final week (inclusive). It will cover any material or information contained (or referred to) in the Lectures, Learning Guide or Tutorials. 

Permitted materials

Any written or printed material is permitted in the exam. Material may also be annotated.

Referencing

References to cases and legislation must be underlined. You may refer to cases and legislation by short names. 

Use of AI

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Academic misconduct may become part of a report that UQ must provide to the Legal Practitioners Admissions Board, and this may impact whether you can be admitted to legal practice.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Below are the topics that will be covered in lectures throughout the semester. Full details are contained in the Law of Contract I Learning Guide. The Learning Guide refers to cases and statutes contained in the Course Materials/Notes volume.

Lectures will take place weekly in person. The lectures will be recorded and the recordings made available via Learn.UQ. Lecture slides will also be made available.

***THERE IS NO LECTURE IN WEEK 10 (WEEK COMMENCING 4 MAY)***

Lecture topics

  1. Introduction and Agreement
  2. Agreement - Offer
  3. Agreement - Acceptance
  4. Certainty and Completeness
  5. Intention to Contract
  6. Consideration
  7. Equitable Estoppel
  8. Formalities
  9. Express Terms
  10. Implied Terms
  11. Interpretation
  12. Unfair Contract Terms

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials

***THERE ARE NO TUTORIALS IN WEEK 1 (WEEK COMMENCING 23 FEB), WEEK 10 (WEEK COMMENCING 4 MAY) OR WEEK 11 (WEEK COMMENCING 11 MAY)***

The tutorial topics are:

  1. Agreement
  2. Certainty and Completeness
  3. Intention to Contract
  4. Consideration
  5. Equitable Estoppel
  6. Formalities
  7. Express and Implied Terms
  8. Interpretation
  9. Unfair Contract Terms

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
